docs.lead_paragraph: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the agency that many Americans love to hate and industry calls overzealous, has largely ignored the slow, silent killers that claim the most lives.

headline.main: As OSHA Emphasizes Safety, Long-Term Health Risks Fester
headline.print_headline: As OSHA Emphasizes Safety, Long-Term Health Risks Fester

docs.abstract: Occupational Safety and Health Administration, agency that many Americans love to hate and industry calls overzealous, has largely ignored long-term health risks; situation is evidenced by rise in use of harmful chemical known as n-propyl bromide, or nPB; OSHA devotes most of its budget and attention to responding to here-and-now dangers rather than preventing silent, slow killers like nPB that ultimately take far more lives.
docs.snippet: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the agency that many Americans love to hate and industry calls overzealous, has largely ignored the slow, silent killers that claim the most lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: CrossFit, the workout fitness program, is viewed by some companies as a way to improve worker production and morale.

headline.seo: CrossFit Offers an Exercise in Corporate Teamwork, Too
headline.main: We’re One Big Team, So Run Those Stairs
headline.print_headline: We’re One Big Team, So Run Those Stairs

docs.abstract: CrossFit, workout fitness program, is viewed by some companies as a way to improve worker production and morale; businesses like Colorado company Datalogix are encouraging employees to participate collectively in intense fitness regimen.
docs.snippet: CrossFit, the workout fitness program, is viewed by some companies as a way to improve worker production and morale.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to “Going It Alone, Together” (March 24).
docs.snippet: Readers respond to “Going It Alone, Together” (March 24).

docs.lead_paragraph: Louisiana’s health secretary, Bruce Greenstein, is resigning amid state and federal inquiries into the awarding of a Medicaid contract to a company where Mr. Greenstein once worked.

headline.main: Louisiana: Health Secretary Resigns Amid Investigations
headline.print_headline: Louisiana: Health Secretary Resigns Amid Investigations

docs.abstract: Louisiana’s health secretary, Bruce Greenstein, is resigning amid state and federal inquiries into the awarding of a Medicaid contract to a company where Greenstein once worked.
docs.snippet: Louisiana’s health secretary, Bruce Greenstein, is resigning amid state and federal inquiries into the awarding of a Medicaid contract to a company where Mr. Greenstein once worked.

docs.lead_paragraph: In response to new federal regulations, institutions are spending millions to help patients avoid returning to the hospital, but some say that the penalties they seek to avoid are unjust.

headline.seo: Hospitals Question Fairness of New Medicare Rules
headline.main: Hospitals Question Medicare Rules on Readmissions
headline.print_headline: Hospitals Questioning Fairness of Medicare Rules on Readmissions

docs.abstract: Institutions are spending millions to help patients avoid returning to hospitals, in response to new federal regulations aimed at reducing costly and unnecessary readmissions; some say the penalties levied on hospitals with high readmission rates are unfair.
docs.snippet: In response to new federal regulations, institutions are spending millions to help patients avoid returning to the hospital, but some say that the penalties they seek to avoid are unjust.

docs.lead_paragraph: The bailout in Cyprus was completed, and banks there reopened, albeit under tight capital controls; T-Mobile, now selling the iPhone, introduced a new billing plan; and a top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was arrested.

headline.main: Pictures From the Week in Business

docs.snippet: The bailout in Cyprus was completed, and banks there reopened, albeit under tight capital controls; T-Mobile, now selling the iPhone, introduced a new billing plan; and a top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was arrested.

headline.main: U.S. Health Care Prices Are the Elephant in the Room

docs.abstract: Until voters demand transparent and equitable pricing, it will be hard for the United States to control health care spending.
docs.snippet: Until voters demand transparent and equitable pricing, it will be hard for the United States to control health care spending.

docs.lead_paragraph: The report, commissioned by the State of California, says that the law will drive up individual insurance premiums, but that subsidies will offset most of the increase for low-income people.

headline.seo: Health Care Law Will Increase Some Premiums, Study Says
headline.main: Health Care Law Will Raise Some Premiums, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Health Care Law Will Raise Some Premiums, Study Says

docs.abstract: Study commissioned by State of California says that federal health care reform law will drive up individual insurance premiums, but that subsidies will offset most of the increase for low-income people; California is far ahead of most states in setting competitive marketplace, or exchange, where people can buy insurance in fall of 2013.
docs.snippet: The report, commissioned by the State of California, says that the law will drive up individual insurance premiums, but that subsidies will offset most of the increase for low-income people.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent statements from both Democrats and Republicans show a possible way forward in curbing Medicare costs, suggesting a lingering, if slight, chance for a budget bargain.

headline.seo: Common Ground in Washington for Medicare Changes
headline.main: Talk of Medicare Changes Could Open Way to Budget Pact
headline.print_headline: Medicare Shift May Lead Way To Budget Pact

docs.abstract: Pres Obama and Congressional Republicans raise idea of broad systemic changes to Medicare that could produce significant savings and end polarizing debate over GOP plans to privatize program; statements from both sides show possible common ground on curbing Medicare costs, suggesting some lingering chance, however small, for budget bargain.
docs.snippet: Recent statements from both Democrats and Republicans show a possible way forward in curbing Medicare costs, suggesting a lingering, if slight, chance for a budget bargain.

byline.original: By JACKIE CALMES and ROBERT PEAR
